entry.title: Wrap up SAP Community Events Melbourne 2025
entry.content:
Following were the events we did this year as part of the SAP Community Melbourne . 

19th Feb

AWS Re: Invent Recap - By David Nye

BDC -  By Sai Sriram

SAP Melbourne Stammtisch April '25

21st May

6.15pm ‚Äì Demystifying Clean Core and the Free Clean Core Assessment Service - Paul Fewster from SAP

7.00pm ‚Äì Empowering RISE with SAP: How Cloud ALM Enables Clean Core and Business Transformation - Shruthi Jayaram from SAP

Global Running Day with SAP Community in Melbourne - Wednesday 4th June 2025

20th Aug

6.30pm ‚Äì AI-assisted Development for BTP Apps and Integrations - Vibe coding experiences in SAP projects

7.00pm ‚Äì  Agentic AI - By David Nye

SAP Stammtisch Melbourne October '25

Code Jam in Melbourne on 17th Nov 25

SAP Stammtisch Melbourne November '25

26th Nov

6.30pm ‚Äì Unleashing the power of AI agents with Joule Studio - Yatsea Li from SAP

7.00pm ‚Äì  Beyond Chat ‚Äî Building Intelligent SAP Skills with Joule Studio - Daljeet Singh from FAIR Consulting

‚ÄÉ

‚ÄÉ

‚ÄÉ

‚ÄÉ

‚ÄÉ

 

We had so much fun and learnt a lot. Have a great time with family and friends during the festive season and catch you in the new year. 

Do not forget we will start with a full day event in March 2026.

So looking forward to hearing from people who are willing to present at the event. 

Planned dates for the next year

14th Mar 2026 - Full Day event 

20th May 2026 -  Tech night

19th Aug 2026 -  Tech night 

19th Nov 2026 - Tech night

Catch you in the new year. 

Advanced Happy New Year 2026 

Cheers,

SAP Melbourne Community 

 

‚ÄÉ

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: singing, acting, advocating and... supporting
entry.content:
Who I am 

My name is Marika Porto, and I work as a Technical Lead Consultant at Mindset, an italian SAP Silver Partner company.
Special thanks to @JanRumig for passing the word on to me - and @smarchesini for pushing me, every day, to get out of my comfort zone a little more üòâ 
Today, I‚Äôd like to share a bit about my hobbies, joining the amazing  SAP Community Hobbies series. 
I have quite a few of them, and I hope some of you might share at least one with me! 
My hobbies play an important role in my life because they help me clear my mind and think more effectively, especially when I face challenging situations at work.
 

Why I decide to sing so awfully that even the clouds start crying

One of my favorite hobbies is singing! About a year ago, I started taking weekly singing lessons with a teacher, and it‚Äôs honestly one of the best things I‚Äôve done for myself lately. Singing has given me a ton of satisfaction‚Äîespecially because I‚Äôve had the courage to perform in front of bigger crowds (over a hundred people!), a song in Sicilian language. 
 
For me, singing is a way to truly connect with myself and focus only on the feelings in my body, which is something I hardly get to do in my daily work life. Paying attention to my tone, volume, and how I position my mouth and lips forces me to be mindful and listen to what‚Äôs going on inside me. Sometimes it hurts, but this self-awareness is such a bonus, both personally and even at work‚Äîit‚Äôs a great stress reliever and confidence booster! Plus, I like to think I‚Äôm not too bad at it: my husband hasn‚Äôt asked for a divorce yet, so I must be on the right track! üòÅ

 
This photo from my latest concert. in July 2025. I sang 'La Fine' - a song write by Francesco Tarducci (aka Nesli).
This song was hard to sing due to its introspective way: 'Arriver√† la fine, ma non sar√† la fine" - It will be the end... but I will never be
 

The best way to learn empathy: acting

My second big passion is acting!
I spend about four hours a week with a local theater group in my city called Lampioni Storti‚Äîthey're super welcoming, even though I have a strong Southern Italian accent and they're all Northerners.
They've let me dive into everything behind the scenes: the training, prep, and all the hard work that goes into staging a comedy. So my gap become something really special, at the end.
 
Acting is huge for me because it teaches real empathy‚Äîyou have to fully step into someone else's shoes and live their story. And since we do comedies, nothing beats hearing the audience laugh; it's pure magic!
 
Next year, I'll even get my shot at a proper acting role, which I'm thrilled about.
 
It was a lot of fun, on March 2025, being the most annoying girlfriend possible in a play.
The audience identified so much that at a certain point they actually started hating me!
But I have to say, I'm pretty good as a blonde... 
 

M71A for women's equality in tech

My third hobby‚Äîand the one I'm most proud of‚Äîis being an activist for M71A, the Italian Manifesto for Equality of Girls and Women in Technology. It's a volunteer-driven group focused on gender equality in tech, tackling the gender gap and the challenges women face breaking through in our industry. Our big goal is cultural awareness to push for real change.
 
I got involved because I want to do my part, especially in the SAP world where I work daily. It's inspiring to fight for a more inclusive tech space where talent shines regardless of gender. 
 
I‚Äôd love to be a role model for someone‚Äîespecially a female role model in tech‚Äîjust like the incredible women who inspired me during my career to dive into technology and SAP. Seeing strong female leaders made all the difference, pushing me to pursue this path despite the challenges. Now, through my activism, I hope to pay it forward and encourage the next generation of women in our field to break barriers and thrive.
 
That's the badge that you can share if you sign the Manifesto. A way to be proud to be part of a important wind of change.

Being a sports supporter = pursuing a common goal together

My fourth hobby‚Äîand probably the most fun of all‚Äîis being a die-hard volleyball fan! From October through March or April, I join the organized supporters group, named "Men In Black Group", for Pallavolo Padova, one of Italy's top SuperLega teams (the premier men's league). Sundays mean chanting new cheers, losing my voice, and dealing with Monday morning throat pain, all while surrounded by a huge crowd with different vibes but the same fiery passion.
 
It's chaos in the best way‚Äîcoordinating with fans who all want different things but pull together for one goal. Being in that energy reminds me how powerful it is to spot a shared objective and row in the same direction, a lesson that translates straight to teamwork at work. 
Being a supporter doesn't mean to join a violent group of people: it's just the opposite. You are in the right place with people that respect the opposite players. No scream, no shout, only positives happy vibes!
And when your favorite team loses, we all think about next time, because there's always a next time.
If you persist and persevere, you'll achieve and conquer!
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
A happy me beating the drum to support the team.
About two hours of play where the only thought is pushing the boys to never give up, as a leader must do everyday!

How to get started and how to achieve your first goals with these hobbies

To get started as a beginner in any of these hobbies, the key essentials aren't gear or fancy resources‚Äîthey're curiosity to dive in and the courage to put yourself out there, facing some of your biggest fears head-on.
 
Things like public speaking, expressing raw emotions, or sharing what you truly care about can feel scary at first, but pushing through builds real confidence that spills over into work and life. Start small, practice with people you trust, and breathe deeply to stay grounded‚Äîit's all about that first step of getting uncomfortable to grow.
 
Any actor, singer, activist, supporter out there?
Let's chat!
 
Love from Marika

entry.title: Gurugram Stammtisch: Invitation to SAP Community Members for 12-Dec-2025 at DLF Cyber Hub, Gurugram
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community Members,

We are happy to invite you to the upcoming SAP Stammtisch, Gurugram ‚Äî an enriching evening of networking, knowledge-sharing, and collaboration.

Date:  Friday, 12 December 2025
Time: 6:30 PM to 8:30 PM
Venue: DLF Cyber Hub, Gurugram ‚Äì 122002

As part of the gathering, we will also discuss and plan next year‚Äôs community events, continuing our tradition of bringing SAP professionals together to exchange insights, experiences, and innovative ideas.

Kindly confirm your participation by submitting your details at the link below on or before 10 December 2025:
üîóhttps://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfwNWsjWcAAA48ER15zSP-tQJcdKk02w7Z24B8ig6R9z44HYg/viewform?usp=dialog

We look forward to your presence and active engagement as we strengthen our SAP community together!

Warm regards,
Ravi Grover
On behalf of the SAP Gurgaon Community Core Team

entry.title: My SAP TechEd 2025: Special SAP Community Moments
entry.content:
Hello everyone!

My name is Moshe Naveh from the SAP Community team. Today I would like to share with you the exceptional experience I had in SAP TechEd Berlin and Bangalore 2025. There isn't a more suitable day to do so but my 16th SAP Community anniversary which is today. Joining the SAP Community back in 2009 enabled me to attend multiple SAP TechEds as I‚Äôve shared in this post. However, this year was my best SAP TechEd year so far! Want to know why? please keep reading below:).

Before we dive into the details of my amazing SAP TechEd 2025 journey, I would like to invite you to an online gathering where we will continue the SAP TechEd magic! SAP Community members will share their personal SAP TechEd experience and highlights and also learn how to quickly share it on the SAP Community using the AI based Simplified blogging methodology. If you're interested in joining, please Email me at community@sap.com and I'll send you more details (currently we're planning for upcoming Thursday, but we'll see what works for everyone).

SAP TechEd Berlin

SAP TechEd Berlin was my first SAP TechEd event after 7 years. That was the case for many people. You could really feel how eager people were to meet again in person. There is something in face to face meeting that you cannot sense via a virtual interaction. During the event I was mainly in the SAP Community booth. It enabled me to do something I really enjoy when meeting SAP Community members and that is to interact, share ideas and insights, smile and laugh and just have good time together. It is what the SAP Community and my community passion is all about. I was also very happy to meet community members who participated in our SAP TechEd speakers series and hear how the simplified methodology helped them:

Sunny Kapoor who spoke about Real-time data for AI agents: Grounding with event-driven architecture

and 

Stephanie Jerch and Christian Niedermayer who had a session about "Discover SAP Cloud ALM for operations in action"

Then I really enjoyed also telling people about the SAP Community Hobbies series and even got some new contributors to join it!

Marla Alschweiki who will share about her lovely dog and more!

And 

Patricia who will share about her lovely hobbies (more details to come!:))

I was also fortunate to finally meet in person community members I've been working with for years, such as KP who does terrific things related to database and analytics in the SAP Community 

One my main challenge during the event was not to eat too much (remember this line! You will hear it again)!

We had a great photographer on site who helped people get their perfect profile picture!:  

 I think it came out nice;):

and talking about photos, one of the things you wonder about during such events after you have not been to them for a while is what changed. I know Christian Braukmuller didn't change!: 

     Exact spot, 11 years and not much changed:)

One of the most important aspects for me in such events is meeting my team! 

Here in the picture awesome SAP Community members and some of my amazing team members, among those responsible for the great community magic during SAP TechEd (including team members not in the picture, holding the fortress back in the office:)) 

      

 

And I couldn't ask for a better last selfie for SAP TechEd Berlin just before I headed home:

         

SAP TechEd Berlin was great and prepared me for the wow experience I was about to have in SAP TechEd Bangalore.

 

SAP TechEd Bangalore

 

So after two weeks break at home, I was fortunate to travel again to SAP TechEd Bangalore. I haven't been to India for a long time as well and I enjoyed every moment in it:).

One of the first things I did after I landed was to go and eat. I was both hungry but I also really missed the Indian food!

I went for the spiciest dish in the menu:

and here you can see the steam on sunglasses from how spicy the food was! (I thought it just happened in cartoons:)) :

Then, after resting a bit from the travel I've reached what I was really after and that was meeting everyone in SAP TechEd Bangalore!

I was so happy meeting everyone and I started taking selfies with SAP Community members to have a memory of those great meetings! Interestingly enough, the second person that I saw and knew, was Jitendra Kansal:

   

Jitendra is an old friend and we first me back in 2012 during my first SAP TechEd ever and after Jitendra was one of the main people who helped me successfully launch and expend the blog it forward challenge!:  

      

 then I got to my booth and I fell in love with the setup. I loved the big touch screen TV and space we got to freely interact and engage with amazing people. When I explained to people who heard about the community for the first time, I was excited as them. Showing different places on the community on the big touch screen made it feel to me like dancing!:

 

It was two amazing days where I didn't stop talking about the great things that are happening in the SAP Community. I met so many great people and existing/new friends. Not many know but it was the first time I did such an engaging interaction in the booth which included a lot of jokes and interesting stories about the SAP Community and myself. Josh Bentely well described as being an educational entertainer! I enjoyed so much talking about my passion to the SAP Community and at the same time making people happy and laugh:):

I admit that I was very moved by the energy and the great spirit of the next generation of the SAP Professionals:

And I also talked about the SAP Community hobbies and was able to prove to the world how go of a painter @Sandra_Solis is (whom I was very fortunate to meet with in Berlin and we agreed we won't forget to take a selfie next time:):

Vitaly is showing how he looks alike his coffee drawing by Sandra Solis

and another great photo filled with community spirit:

 

And talking about community spirit, the Developer advocates rocked it during the entire event (also in SAP TechEd Berlin):

I love the Indian culture! I love the people, food, music and dance! Couldn't think of a better way to finish my own personal SAP TechEd tour with a great show and dancing like no one is watching:):

So SAP TechEd 2025 was an amazing experience that we all, and especially me, were waiting for so long. I'm sure that you and I will see fruits of the great SAP Community booth interactions and that I will stay in touch with my new SAP Community friends.

Looking forward to seeing all of you in the SAP Community and in future events!

Please join us, SAP Community members and the Community team for an SAP Teched gathering where we will connect, share experiences and learn how to quickly share them in the SAP Community. Please Email me at community@sap.com if you would like to join the gathering.

Please share in the comments section how was SAP TechEd for you and if you have picture of us together, please share!:)

entry.title: A Day of Innovation, Insight & Intelligent Conversations: SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025
entry.content:
A Day of Innovation, Insight & Intelligent Conversations: SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025

SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025 was more than an event ‚Äî it was a full day of learning, exchange of ideas, and meaningful community moments. Hosted with the support of AWS, Mindset, ROJO Integrations, and SAP Press, the gathering brought together professionals from across the SAP ecosystem: developers, consultants, architects, leaders, learners, and enthusiasts.

Right from the first interaction at the registration desk, there was a sense of purpose and curiosity in the air. Everyone walked in with a shared goal: to understand where the world of enterprise technology is heading next.

SAP GGN Community Core Team for SAP Insider Track GGN 2025 ‚Äì Third Edition

 

A Warm and Powerful Beginning

The day began with organized registrations and structured networking, giving participants the opportunity to connect and align their expectations for the event. The event kicked off with a warm welcome from Aseem Khera, Location Head, ‚ÄãSAP Labs India Gurugram‚Äã clearly outlining the agenda and highlighting the day‚Äôs objectives. His opening remarks established a clear framework and set the tone for subsequent sessions.

Aseem Khera, Location Head, ‚ÄãSAP Labs India Gurugram‚Äã 

 

This was followed by an inspiring video keynote from Sindhu Gangadharan, Managing Director of SAP Labs India, Head of SAP Customer Innovation Services, and SAP Chairperson of NASSCOM. In her address, she highlighted the importance of the SAP Community, the effects of artificial intelligence on the global economy, and SAP's AI-First, Suite-First strategy.

Sindhu Gangadharan, Managing Director of SAP Labs India, Head of SAP Customer Innovation Services, and SAP Chairperson of NASSCOM

 

 

The morning session continued with an inspiring SAP Business AI strategy talk by Sudhir Verma, Head of Technology & Architecture ‚ÄãPrivate Cloud Products titled ‚ÄúTransforming Business with SAP Business AI.‚Äù He provided a comprehensive and insightful overview of the ongoing transformation of SAP Business AI strategy.

Sudhir Verma, Head of Technology & Architecture ‚ÄãPrivate Cloud Products

 

A huge shout-out to our amazing host, Akansha Tiwari! Your energy, charm, and effortless hosting truly made the event unforgettable. Your poised and engaging presence kept the momentum alive throughout the entire morning session. The way you connected with the audience, guided transitions with ease, and maintained a vibrant atmosphere played a pivotal role in the event‚Äôs overall success.

 

Akansha Tiwari - Host of the Event

 

 

Three Tracks, Three Journeys, One Purpose

The event went beyond treating technology as a concept, organizing learning into three parallel tracks tailored to different participant needs. Each track offered practical, actionable insights‚Äîcatering to leaders, developers, and hands-on learners alike‚Äîallowing attendees to explore strategies, tools, and real-world applications in a focused and meaningful way aligned with their roles and professional goals.

Agenda of the day with Session Title & Speaker Names

 

Track 01: SAP Business AI Strategy & Roadmap‚Äã / SAP Business AI Products

Ideal for architects, leaders, and decision-makers

This track focused on understanding how organizations can evolve their systems, processes, and governance models. Speakers shared their experiences on:

  • Strengthening enterprise value
  • Navigating regulatory landscapes
  • Modernizing GRC
  • Evolving SuccessFactors experiences
  • Positioning SAP‚Äôs latest offerings for business outcomes

The conversations weren‚Äôt theoretical‚Äîthey were grounded in real decisions and real impact.

 

Track 02: Embedded AI in SAP Solutions‚Äã / Building with SAP AI Agents‚Äã

Built for developers, engineers, and product builders

This track showcased what happens when ideas take shape. From building custom solutions to exploring new toolkits, participants learned how to translate concepts into working applications.

Sessions covered:

  • Building custom agents
  • Optimizing catalogs
  • Ensuring safety in high-risk industries
  • Handling real-time situations in S/4HANA
  • Enhancing HR processes with modern tools

Every session was centered around solving real business challenges.

 

Track 03: Hands-On Workshops

For those who understand best by doing

This track remained one of the most crowded for a reason‚Äîit was all action.

Participants practiced:

  • Generate an SAP Fiori app from an image‚Äã
  • Generate an SAP Fiori app from business requirements‚Äã
  • Generate and enhance an app‚Äã
  • Develop an Enterprise-Grade CAP‚Äã

It was a genuine ‚Äúroll-up-your-sleeves‚Äù experience.

 

Afternoon Deep Dives: Practical Stories & Lessons

Post lunch, the sessions transitioned to in-depth case studies and practical, real-world scenarios. Speakers provided valuable insights on topics such as:

  • Detecting fraud within business systems
  • Optimizing development cycles
  • Managing responsible digital processes
  • Enhancing commercial operations
  • Improving employee experiences in live environments

These discussions effectively bridged technology with day-to-day organizational decisions, demonstrating tangible applications and measurable outcomes for participants.

 

The Heart of the Day: Conversations & Community

SAP Inside Track events have always been known for their community-driven spirit. Gurugram 2025 continued that legacy beautifully.

Corridors, break areas, and even the workshop tables stayed alive with:

  • Debates on implementation challenges
  • Exchange of tips and best practices
  • Discussions on new roles and skills
  • Shared excitement for the future of enterprise systems

For many, these conversations were just as valuable as the sessions themselves.

 

A Fitting Closure

The day wrapped up with a closing ceremony followed by snacks and informal networking. People walked out with new connections, refreshed perspectives, and a deeper appreciation for how powerful the SAP community is when it comes together.

ÔºàChange has never been this fast, and it will never be this slow againÔºâ

ÁßÅ„Åü„Å°„ÅØ‰ªä„ÄÅÊ≠¥Âè≤ÁöÑ„Å™Ëª¢ÊèõÁÇπ„Å´„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

[English Version]

Event Report: ASUG Tech Connect 2025: JSUG Technical Committee's Perspective on the SAP Ecosystem via Berlin and North America

Disclaimer:

This article represents the personal views of the author based on their experience as an Opinion Leader of the JSUG Technical Committee and does not represent the official views of their affiliated company or organizations such as JSUG. Parts of this document were created with the assistance of Generative AI. We do not guarantee the accuracy of the content, so please use the information at your own discretion.

This article is written for the SAP Advent Calendar 2025 (December 15th).

Introduction: Seeking the "Mainstream" of Technology and the "Heat Source" of Community

Recently, "ASUG Tech Connect 2025" was held in Louisville, Kentucky.

Although this is the third year for this event, we at the JSUG (Japan SAP Users' Group) Technical Committee have participated every year since its inception (2023), regularly monitoring the enthusiasm and trends on the ground.

This year, the JSUG Technical Committee took a strategic approach.

We dispatched two members to "SAP TechEd Berlin," the main event where SAP's latest technologies are announced, to catch up on the "mainstream" of technology. Meanwhile, we dispatched three members, including myself, to "ASUG Tech Connect" here in North America.

Why did we dare to split the team and travel to North America?

This event was born out of a strong local will that "a place for face-to-face gathering is necessary" when SAP TechEd in North America became virtual in the past. Although SAP TechEd has now returned to in-person formats, ASUG Tech Connect has undergone its own unique evolution as an event that prioritizes "the significance of people gathering" above all else.

The latest technology (Berlin) and its practice/community (ASUG).

We report on the collaboration with SAP TechEd and the message unique to ASUG regarding "Human Transformation," which became visible precisely because we dispatched members to both sides.

 

 

 

1. Powerful Collaboration with SAP TechEd Berlin: The "Perfect Companions" Across the Ocean

This year, ASUG Tech Connect was clearly defined as "The perfect companions" to SAP TechEd. This is because, as "The Official North American SAP TechEd Tour Event," it is completely synchronized with the global event in the following three points:

  • Sharing Content (Hands-on):

    Technical sessions and hands-on materials announced at SAP TechEd Berlin were provided as-is at the North American venue. For example, sessions on Generative AI and Fiori app development included guidance to "Try the hands-on from SAP TechEd Berlin," enabling the same technical experience as in Berlin while being in North America.

  • Providing Certification:

    The venue offered opportunities to obtain the latest SAP certifications such as "SAP Build Developer" and "SAP Generative AI Developer" at no additional cost.

  • Real-time Collaboration:

    In the keynote, SAP's Muhammad Alam participated via live broadcast from the SAP TechEd venue in Berlin. It was emphasized that both events are transmitting a unified message, transcending physical distance.

 

 

 

2. The Core of the Keynote: Transform "People" Rather Than Technology

The keynote, the highlight of the event, consisted of two parts: the "Opening" on the first day and the "Partner & Customer Stories" on the third day.

What ASUG CEO Geoff Scott and SAP leaders broadcasted here was a powerful message concerning our careers and the survival of our organizations, going beyond mere introductions of new features. This is the biggest difference from SAP TechEd, which focuses on technology announcements.

"Change has never been this fast, and it will never be this slow again"

First, I want to share a phrase that symbolizes the modern era, which was repeatedly cited throughout the event.

"Change has never been this fast, and it will never be this slow again"

We are now at a historical turning point.

In the customer panel, a fact was contrasted: "It took 500 years for Gutenberg's printing press to spread, whereas ChatGPT reached 1 million users in just 5 days."

Also, SAP's Mayank Shrivastava pointed out that the evolution cycle of AI models is at a "frightening pace," shortening from an update interval of about 10 months previously to just 7 weeks for the latest models.

In this "irreversible acceleration," how should we behave?

Discard "Yesterday" and Move to "Learn-it-all"

In response to this question, Dr. Walter Sun, SAP's Global Head of AI, presented two important guidelines.

  1. Stop Optimizing Yesterday

    "Stop optimizing what we have done yesterday."

    It is essential not to merely improve efficiency of existing processes with AI, but to rethink the processes themselves from the ground up and have the curiosity to experiment.

  2. From "Know-it-all" to "Learn-it-all"

    Then, "Learn-it-all" was presented as the mindset transformation.

    • Know-it-all: An attitude of clinging to past knowledge and being overconfident that one knows everything.

    • Learn-it-all: An attitude of trying to learn new things every day.

    Barriers to entry for AI are low, and anyone can try it immediately. That is why whether you can cycle through "Experimentation" becomes the dividing line for victory, rather than the amount of knowledge.

Support through Technology and Teams

Of course, it was not just about mindset. Concrete "weapons" and "cases" were also shared.

  • Weapons for Developers:

    Muhammad Alam and Yaad Oren stated that investment in a "Clean Data Layer (Business Data Cloud)" is paramount to respond to changes happening in 7-week units. Also, the opening of SAP Build (VS Code extensions, etc.) was announced to resolve backlogs, promising an environment where developers can fight using familiar tools.

  • Transformation is a Team Sport:

    In the keynote on the third day, cases such as PepsiCo (AI/Copilot utilization), HP (ERP modernization), and Int4 (test automation) were shared.

    In particular, the "Show and Tell" sessions by companies like John Deere demonstrated not just clean slides but the "gritty practical knowledge" of how the whole team overcame challenges, serving as a learning ground with reality unique to ASUG.

 

 

 

3. Analysis: What is the Difference Between SAP TechEd Berlin and ASUG Tech Connect?

Synthesizing the perspectives of JSUG members who participated in both Berlin and ASUG, we can see that while both events share the "Same Technology Strategy (What)," there is a clear division of roles in "Who they tell it to and How (Who & How)."

Commonalities (The "What")

Both events are completely aligned on technical core messages.

  • The Era of AI Agents: Focus on "Autonomous AI (Joule Agents)" beyond chatbots.

  • Openness to Developers: Fusion with open standard technologies such as SAP Build VS Code extensions.

  • Clean Core: Utilization of "Clean Data Layer" and BTP as the foundation for innovation.

Differences (The "Focus")

However, their focus differs significantly.

FeatureSAP TechEd Berlin (Global)ASUG Tech Connect (North America)
Catch MessageWhere ideas get real.Real Skills. Real People. Real Impact.
Main Focus"Technology and Roadmap""Professional Transformation"
Perspective on AIFunctionality and Possibility (What AI can do)Responsibility and Skills (How humans use AI)
Case StudiesShowcase of SAP TechnologySharing Gritty Practical Knowledge (Show and Tell)
DirectionVendor to User (Vision)User to User Mutual Aid (Community)

In other words, while Berlin is a place to hand over the "Latest Weapons (Technology)," ASUG Tech Connect can be said to be a place to nurture the "Users (People)."

 

 

 

‚ÄÉ

‚ÄÉ

‚ÄÉ

Summary: Let's Energize the Japanese Community Precisely Because We Share the Same Struggles

"Business transformation does not happen without professional transformation"

This phrase was spoken by ASUG CEO Geoff Scott in the opening keynote of ASUG Tech Connect.

Implementing technology (AI or S/4HANA) alone does not change business. It is an absolute condition for success that we, who handle it, discard old habits and acquire new skills and mindsets (= professional transformation).

However, while we individuals have hope for capability expansion through AI, I think there is also anxiety about being required to transform into a constantly learning "Learn-it-all."

Furthermore, looking at organizations, we face walls that are not easily overcome, such as data preparation, cultural acceptance, and security responsibilities.

Through this participation, I found a certain "reality" that I desperately want to convey to you all.

While touching on the latest technology at the venue, networking with ASUG Community members revealed unexpected words from them.

"We are busy with the maintenance of existing systems and cannot get around to new technologies."

"We know transformation is necessary, but the organization doesn't follow."

Even engineers in North America, which is said to be an IT-advanced region, were actually facing exactly the same worries as us and fighting ongoing problems.

The keynote's warning that "Change has never been this fast" was a heavy reality for them as well.

We are not alone. And it is not just Japan that is lagging behind.

Now that the whole world is facing the same wall, the meaning of the question thrown by ASUG CEO Geoff Scott resonates even more strongly.

"Why go alone when we can go together?"

No matter how excellent individual skills are, the risk of fighting in isolation in this torrent is too great.

Just as users in North America are gathering at ASUG to support each other, we also need to strengthen the power of the Japanese community more.

There are diverse "places to connect" in Japan: not just the SAP Community here, but also external study groups, online forums, partner communities, and user groups like ours.

We will share the insights we grabbed in Berlin and North America through various opportunities. Let's energize the entire Japanese community, share wisdom with each other (Collective wisdom), and ride over this wave of change together.

I look forward to heating up the discussion with you all at various community venues.

entry.title: Hello SAP Community Chemnitz
entry.content:
*** english below ***

Willkommen in der SAP Community Local Group Chemnitz!

Diese Gruppe ist eine lokale Plattform f√ºr alle, die sich in Chemnitz und der Region f√ºr SAP interessieren. Ganz gleich, ob du t√§glich mit SAP-L√∂sungen arbeitest, als Berater:in, Entwickler:in oder Analyst:in t√§tig bist, studierst oder einfach neugierig auf SAP-Themen bist ‚Äì du bist hier herzlich willkommen.

Unser Ziel ist es, einen Raum f√ºr pers√∂nlichen Austausch und Vernetzung zu schaffen. Wir sind √ºberzeugt davon, dass der direkte Austausch von Angesicht zu Angesicht besonders wertvoll ist, um Erfahrungen zu teilen, Ideen zu diskutieren und voneinander zu lernen.

Chemnitz und die umliegende Region bieten eine starke Basis aus Industrie, Technologie und Innovation, erg√§nzt durch eine vielf√§ltige akademische Landschaft mit Hochschulen und Forschungseinrichtungen als wichtigen Teil des lokalen √ñkosystems. Wir m√∂chten Menschen aus Industrie, Beratung, Wissenschaft und dar√ºber hinaus miteinander vernetzen.

Unser erster Fokus liegt klar auf pers√∂nlichen Treffen vor Ort. Geplant sind entspannte Meetups und informelle Zusammenk√ºnfte wie ein Stammtisch, bei denen sich SAP-Interessierte und SAP-Professionals austauschen, voneinander lernen und gemeinsam ein starkes lokales Netzwerk aufbauen k√∂nnen. Informationen zu kommenden Veranstaltungen teilen wir hier in der Gruppe.

Diese Community lebt von der Beteiligung ihrer Mitglieder. Alle, die die Idee des offenen Austauschs und der Zusammenarbeit teilen, sind eingeladen, sich einzubringen, Themen vorzuschlagen oder zuk√ºnftige Events mitzugestalten. Wenn du dich aktiver an der Organisation oder Kuration der Gruppe beteiligen m√∂chtest, melde dich gern.

Wir freuen uns darauf, eine lebendige SAP Community in Chemnitz aufzubauen und viele spannende Gespr√§che pers√∂nlich vor Ort zu f√ºhren.

Willkommen in der Gruppe!

Viele Gr√º√üe
Pierre und Jens

Welcome to the SAP Community Local Group Chemnitz!

This group is a local platform for everyone in and around Chemnitz who is interested in SAP. Whether you work with SAP solutions in your daily business, are a consultant, developer, analyst, student, or simply curious about SAP topics, you are very welcome to join us.

Our main goal is to create a space for personal exchange and networking. We strongly believe in the value of meeting face to face, sharing experiences directly, and discussing challenges and ideas in an open and relaxed atmosphere.

Chemnitz and the surrounding region offer a strong foundation of industry, technology, and innovation, supported by a diverse academic landscape with universities and research institutions as an important part of the local ecosystem. We want to connect people from industry, consulting, academia, and beyond who are part of this ecosystem.

Our first focus is clearly on meeting in person. We are planning relaxed meetups and informal get-togethers (Stammtisch) where SAP professionals and interested people can exchange ideas, learn from each other, and grow a strong local network. You will find updates on upcoming events right here in the group.

This community lives from participation. Everyone who shares the idea of open exchange and collaboration is invited to contribute, bring in topics, or help shape future events. If you are interested in getting more actively involved in organizing or curating the group, feel free to reach out.

We are looking forward to building a vibrant SAP community in Chemnitz and to many great conversations in person and on site.

Welcome to the group!

Best regards
Pierre and Jens

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: AI Insights, SAP Community Memories, and What‚Äôs Coming in 2026!
entry.content:
Today marks the final edition of Community Voice for 2025, and we are happy to bring you great featured blog posts, valuable insights from one of our SAP Mentors, and wonderful memories from SAP TechEd. Looking back, we are incredibly proud of our SAP community members for their contributions, energy, and commitment to helping others, sharing experiences, and making the SAP ecosystem an inspiring place to be part of. 

This edition is also a moment to express our gratitude to you, our readers, who continuously engage with our content. Without your support and participation, none of this would be possible. Thank you for being here and for showing up to so many other community members. 

While this newsletter takes a short break during the holiday season, we want to let you know that we will be back at the beginning of January 2026. For now, let‚Äôs look at what has been happening in the SAP Community over the past few weeks and what exciting events are planned for the year ahead! 

Let‚Äôs dive in! 

Featured Blog Posts

Reflections about how far AI will go  

The more we talk about AI, the more people tend to pick sides. Whether you like it or not, the implementation of Artificial Intelligence is accelerating everywhere, and this year SAP demonstrated how well it is prepared to bring powerful AI solutions to its customers. SAP Community member and former SAP employee Pierre Col, who recently retired, opened an important discussion about this topic. In his blog post, he highlights how strongly SAP is positioned in the market and showcases the power of its AI offerings. At the same time, he raises concerns about the impact that AI, and humanoid robots in particular, may have on human employment. Overall, this is a valuable blog post that encourages thoughtful reflection on what the near future may look like and invites the community to share ideas, perspectives, and engage in meaningful discussion in the comments. 

Read Pierre full blog post here 

Guide to Accessibility in SAP Fiori/UI5 for beginners  

If you are looking to understand what accessibility really is in UI development, common pitfalls in UI5 apps and how to start building accessible features without feeling overwhelmed, this blog post is for you. SAP¬¥s Guruprasad, shares a personal journey of discovering why accessibility is not extra work, but a fundamental part of building usable applications, particularly when working with SAP Fiori and UI5. Through practical examples, he introduces useful tools and techniques for testing accessibility, including keyboard-only navigation, screen readers, contrast checkers, and browser inspection tools. This is a beginner-friendly and practical guide for everyone who wants to build inclusive, high-quality SAP UI applications.  

Read Guruprasad full blog post here 

SAP Mentor Leonardo Araujo insights on AI journey at SAP TechEd 2025  

One of the most valuable aspects of SAP TechEd 2025 was the insightful sessions delivered by experienced developers and industry experts. We had the pleasure of hearing from many SAP Mentors and Champions who brought important conversations to the spotlight, and one of the standout sessions was presented by SAP Mentor Leonardo Araujo. His session was based on his earlier blog post‚ÄùThe AI Stack Is Ready ‚Äî Are You? The Challenge No Longer Is Technology‚Äú. Leonardo explained that the AI technology stack, especially for generative and agent-based AI, is already largely in place. Capabilities such as secure AI, RAG scenarios, agent building, orchestration, and flexible LLM choices are now well supported by SAP BTP and reinforced by recent SAP innovations announced at SAP TechEd. He also emphasized key realities of generative AI, including its probabilistic nature, the critical importance of clearly defined problem statements, and the risks of applying AI to broken or poorly designed processes. Therefore, Leonardo shared practical recommendations around experimentation, fail-fast approaches, and the journey from pilot to production. His content is a must-read, offering valuable insights into why some AI pilots fail and how organizations can achieve success. 

Read Leonardo Araujo full blog post here 

SAP Cloud ALM: Codeless Automation for RISE Transitions 

Nowadays, regression testing often becomes a challenge because of the necessity teams need to balance thorough test coverage with the pressure to release quickly. SAP¬¥s Paulo Boschetti explores how Tricentis Test Automation for SAP integrated with SAP Cloud ALM can help teams address this challenge in a more practical way. Paulo explains that tools only succeed when supported by strong testing practices, clear strategies, and skilled teams. While Tricentis TTA offers a powerful, codeless, and SaaS-based approach, its real value comes from enabling functional teams to actively participate in automation rather than replacing testing expertise. Considering real-world implementations in Latin America, particularly during RISE with SAP transitions and S/4HANA upgrades, he shows how this solution significantly reduces regression testing effort and accelerates delivery cycles. He also makes sure to remind readers to‚ÄØinvest equally in your team by training them and supporting skills development.  

Read Paulo Boschetti full blog post here 

Community News 

SAP TechEd 2025: Moshe Naveh Recap  

SAP TechEd 2025 was definitely a highlight of the year for the SAP Community, and Community Advocate Moshe Naveh shared an engaging recap of his experience, highlighting some of the great moments he spent with community members in Berlin and Bengaluru. In his blog post, he reflects on how refreshing it was to return to on-site events, especially since his last SAP TechEd attendance was seven years ago. Moshe also encourages community members to keep the momentum going through online gatherings and continued engagement. For those feeling inspired to share their own stories, he previously published a helpful guide on using an AI-based simplified blogging methodology, making it easier for anyone to start contributing and sharing their experiences with the community. 

SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025 

At the end of November, one of the most anticipated events for the SAP Community Gurugram location group took place: SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025. The event offered a full day of learning and idea exchange among community members and SAP developers, consultants, architects and many more. Hosted at SAP Labs India in Gurugram, the event opened with a keynote by Sindhu Gangadharan, Managing Director of SAP Labs India, Head of SAP Customer Innovation Services, and SAP Chairperson of NASSCOM. Alongside the keynote, the agenda covered a wide range of SAP topics presented by multiple speakers and lots of network breaks. The day concluded with a closing ceremony followed by snacks and informal talks, giving attendees the opportunity to connect. If you would like to explore more highlights (or check if you appear in any of the photos) be sure to read SAP¬¥s Neeraj Manocha latest blog post here for a full recap of the SIT Gurugram! 

SAP ALM Summit North America 2026

To keep the energy going, we would like to remind everyone about the upcoming SAP ALM Summit North America 2026! This event is the chance to boost your ALM value by learning from real-life customer experiences. Expand your knowledge through hands-on labs and attending expert-led sessions.  Some of the amazing speakers that will be presenting at the event are Tim Steuer - VP Customer Communications & Relations SAP SE, S√∂ren Ruder- Head of Customer Experience & Solutions (CXS) SAP SE, Joshua Greenbaum- Principal of Enterprise Applications Consulting EAC and Todd Crandall- Head of Customer Services & Delivery SAP North America. Make sure to register for the event here: SAP ALM Summit NA 2026. 

2026 Upcoming Events

As 2025 comes to an end, we are already looking ahead to 2026 with many exciting plans! SAP community location groups have already added dates for upcoming gatherings to their agendas, giving you the perfect opportunity to mark your calendar early and plan ahead. These events are a great chance to connect, learn, and meet fellow SAP community members in your area.  

Check out the list below to see the events already scheduled for 2026: 

  • 20 of January: SAP CodeJam - Build AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Bielefeld, Germany) 
  • 21 of January: SAP CodeJam - Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core ( Hyderabad, India ) 
  • 22 of January: SAP CodeJam ABAP: SAP BTP, ABAP Environment & RAP ( Hyderabad, India ) 
  • 23 of January: SAP Stammtisch Wroclaw - January Edition! (Registration is closed) 
  • 29 of January: SAP Build: Advanced Event Mesh - Event based SAP Build Process Automation (Bengaluru, India) 
  • 09 of February: Build AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Pune, India) 
  • 26 of February: ‚ÄØBuild AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Gent, Belgium) 
  • 14 of March: SAP Inside Track Joinville 2026 ‚Äì Brasil 
  • 17 of March: SAP TALK WOMEN CWB 2026- Curitiba, Brasil 
  • 14 - 16 of April: SAP ALM Summit NA 2026- Pennsylvania, United States
  • 26 of September: SAP Inside Track Porto 2026 - Portugal 
  • 31 of October: SAP Inside Track Fortaleza 2026- Brasil  

Happy Holidays!  

We would like to express our sincere gratitude to the entire SAP community for the passion, collaboration, and knowledge you share every day. Your contributions and willingness to support one another are what makes this community so special. 2025 was a wonderful year, filled with meaningful lessons and lasting memories, whether online or on-site. Every SAP Inside Track, Stammtisch, meet-up, and even informal conversation made a significant impact, strengthening our connections and contributing to the growth of our community. We wish you a joyful holiday season with peace, happiness, and time with loved ones. We look forward to continuing this journey together in 2026. Happy holidays from all of us in the SAP Community!

entry.title: Stop Building From Scratch: Unlocking SAP Cloud Integration‚Äôs Standard Content
entry.content:
A few months ago, I joined a project where the integration team was spending weeks designing mappings, data models, and error-handling frameworks for processes that were all quite common in business environments.

Sales Orders, Customers, Accounts and other Business Objects

The system landscape was straightforward:
SAP S/4HANA on the backend, Salesforce as the CRM, and the business just wanted data to flow seamlessly between the two.

The team had already started building everything manually:

  • Canonical models for Business Partners
  • Transformations to Salesforce Accounts
  • Retry frameworks and error handling
After Six weeks of design workshops, not a single iFlow was built yet.
At one point, I asked: ‚ÄúHave we checked the Discover space in SAP CI for pre-built Salesforce content?‚Äù
The answer was a confident:  "No. We always build our own.‚Äù
 
Fast forward a few hours later, we sat together and opened Discover.

Most of what they were planning to design had already been developed by SAP, ready to use, specifically for S/4HANA to Salesforce integration, available in the Discover space of SAP Cloud Integration.

There are pre-built integration flows for:

  • Business Partner ‚Üî Account
  • Order ‚Üî Opportunity status
  • Customer master synchronization
  • Error handling and notifications

Instead of designing everything from scratch, all they needed to do was deploy, configure, and extend where necessary.

And this experience has repeated itself across multiple customers, industries, and systems, teams spending months designing integrations that SAP had already delivered as out-of-the-box content.

Not because the team enjoy reinventing the wheel,
but because they simply didn‚Äôt know the wheel already existed.

So, this blog is for everyone who is still building everything from scratch, not because they want to, but because they don‚Äôt know that SAP already provides out-of-the-box integration content.

 

What Is Standard Integration Content?

In simple terms, it‚Äôs SAP‚Äôs way of saying: ‚ÄúHere are prebuilt integration flows, mappings, APIs, and business objects. You don‚Äôt need to start from zero.‚Äù

This content is:

  • Built by SAP
  • Delivered as part of your Integration Suite license
  • Designed for common business processes
  • Packaged with best practices and enterprise patterns

Think of it as Lego blocks.
SAP gives you the pieces, and you assemble what fits your scenario.

 

But How Much Content Are We Talking About?

Here‚Äôs the scale people don‚Äôt realize:

700+ Integration Packages and nearly 4000 iFlows delivered out-of-the-box by SAP.

 

This isn‚Äôt just ‚Äúsome content‚Äù.
It‚Äôs an entire ecosystem of reusable assets built to accelerate enterprise integration.

 

Reality Check: Actual time needed to build integrations

In many organizations, a typical integration project goes like this:

Classic approach (manual build)

  • 6‚Äì8 weeks of design
  • 6‚Äì10 weeks of development
  • Testing + refinements

Total: 12‚Äì20 weeks

 

With Standard Integration Content

  • Deploy existing flows
  • Configure mappings
  • Tailor business-specific logic

Total: 2‚Äì6 weeks

What‚Äôs in the Box?

Standard content includes:
  • Pre-built iFlows
  • Value mappings
  • Event-based integrations
  • Error handling logic
  • Industry-specific templates
  • Configuration Guide
Some packages even include complete integration scenarios. You don‚Äôt just get sample content, You get deployment-ready accelerators.
 

Out-of-the-Box‚Äù Means Out-of-the-Budget

Here‚Äôs the part that surprises most people: There is no additional cost for this. As long as you have a valid license for SAP Integration Suite, you already have access to the standard integration content.

There‚Äôs no marketplace fee.
There‚Äôs no premium tier.
There‚Äôs no ‚Äúenterprise unlock‚Äù.

 

Where Do You Find It?

If you‚Äôve never explored it, here‚Äôs how to get started:
  1. Open SAP Integration Suite
  2. Go to Discover
  3. Search for apps or domains (e.g., SuccessFactors, Salesforce, Ariba)

 

  1. Review package
  2. Copy and adapt

 

As soon as you copy the package, it gets visible in the design tab of your tenant, Now the package is ready to be used. You can configure, modify and make it ready to use.

If you‚Äôre new to SAP CI, take 30 minutes and browse, it will change how you approach integration forever.

 

Why Use Standard Content?

Here‚Äôs the business value:
  1. Faster delivery
    Skip the blueprinting for obvious processes.
  2. Lower risk
    SAP delivers content that is tested, versioned, and updated.
  3. SAP Support and Maintenance
    Support is provided by SAP and updates are released if any.
  4. Best practices by default
    You don‚Äôt have to reinvent canonical models or data mappings.
  5. More time for innovation
    Deliver outcomes, not just interfaces.

My favorite way to summarize it: SAP builds 70-80% of the technical plumbing. You only customize what makes your business unique.

 

Customize, Don‚Äôt Copy-Paste

A common misconception is: ‚ÄúStandard content means I have to use it the way it comes.‚Äù
The answer is: "No"

You can:

  • Extend mappings
  • Add enrichment logic
  • Build wrapper services
  • Add error or retry mechanisms

 SAP expects you to tailor it.

The goal is not reuse OR customize.
The goal is reuse AND customize smartly.

But here‚Äôs a very important nuance that many teams overlook:

When you directly modify a standard integration flow, SAP continues to support the standard baseline, but not the customized version. From that point on, you own the lifecycle of the changes.  And honestly, it makes complete sense. Because once you‚Äôve edited it, SAP has no visibility into:

  • What you changed
  • Why you changed it
  • Whether your changes break functional assumptions

 So they can‚Äôt be accountable for something they didn‚Äôt design or test.

This doesn‚Äôt mean ‚Äúdon‚Äôt customize‚Äù.

There are smarter patterns teams follow to balance reuse + support:

  • Overlay mappings instead of rewriting
  • Wrap standard content in a parent orchestrator
  • Avoid editing the original package unless absolutely necessary
  • Clone only when you fully ‚Äúown‚Äù the lifecycle

 In other words:

Standard content should be reused wherever feasible and extended cautiously when required. Customization should be undertaken only when full ownership and support responsibility can be assumed, ensuring faster delivery and long-term stability.
 

But Let‚Äôs Be Honest

Standard content is not perfect.

Sometimes:

  • The business process doesn‚Äôt match your reality
  • Documentation is light
  • Customization becomes unavoidable

That‚Äôs okay. Think of standard content as a foundation, not a finished building.

It saves you weeks of work.Not all the work.

 

The Mindset Shift

The biggest barrier to adoption is not technology, its culture. Many Integration Teams have this default behavior:
‚ÄúOpen Integration Suite ‚Üí Create iFlow ‚Üí Start designing‚Äù
But the better question is: ‚ÄúHas SAP already solved this problem for me?‚Äù
 
We don‚Äôt get awards for reinventing wheels, We get value from delivering outcomes faster.
 

Real-World Examples

Here are real scenarios where standard content gave teams a head start:
  • Salesforce Integration with SAP Signavio Process Intelligence
  • SAP S/4HANA Integration with Coupa
  • SAP S/4HANA Integration with Zycus

What would normally take 6-8 weeks of design + development
sometimes went live in 2-3 weeks with tailoring.

 

Wrapping Up

SAP Cloud Integration doesn‚Äôt just give you a platform. It gives you content, knowledge, and patterns out-of-the-box.
And yet, so many organizations overlook it spending time, budget, and energy on things that are already there.
 
So the next time someone says: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll build the integration from scratch.‚Äù
Ask them: ‚ÄúOr should we check what SAP already provides?‚Äù
It‚Äôs a small question with massive impact.
 

Join the Conversation

Standard Integration Content in SAP CI continues to grow because practitioners share real-world experiences, gaps, and ideas. If you come across a business scenario or integration use case where standard content is missing or doesn‚Äôt fully meet your needs, don‚Äôt keep it to yourself, share it in the comments or reach out. Your feedback truly matters.

Have you already used Standard Integration Content in SAP Cloud Integration? What worked well, what didn‚Äôt, and what surprised you along the way? Share your experiences, lessons, and tips, because the SAP community learns fastest when we learn together and every insight helps make the standard content more relevant for everyone.

Hope this helps!

 

Cheers,
Punith

entry.title: Enhancements to SAP Community - December 2025
entry.content:
Kudos are now Likes 

The year is ending, and it is also time to say goodbye to our Kudos! Starting now, our thumbs-up for blog posts, comments, and all types of content is again Likes. This change comes from the feedback we have received from our users and our desire to make the platform more intuitive to use. From now on, whenever you read a valuable post or want to show your support, you can simply press the Like button and show your appreciation to the author and wider community. 

End of the pilot for blog post reading view 

Back in August this year, we announced the start of the pilot reading experience for blog posts. This pilot began in response to users who felt that readability was affected and that too much information on the page could be distracting. The right sidebar column for widgets was removed to enable a full-width blog post reading view. However, after analyzing users feedback provided to us in the comments section of the announcement post, we decided to return to the old format, and have therefore now reintroduced the sidebar column for the blog post article reading view.  
On large displays, with the text flowing to a 100% horizontally, it was clear that the reading experience did not improve. If there is any interest, we could try a 4/5 width reading view, like the new view for the individual SAP Managed tag pages. The 4/5 width view is a view without the sidebar column and would ensure the text doesn‚Äôt flow to 100% width on large displays. Please let us know in the comments section below.  

October ‚Äì November platform updates 

With the start of the SAP TechEd month, we all got caught up in the excitement of the on-site events. But while all of this was happening, great new features were also released on our SAP Community Platform. The main enhancements were:  

  • Filter My Content by Interaction Style: It is now possible to filter the My Content Page by interaction style to make it easier to find posts you've created. There are separate tabs for the various post tabs including Answers and Replies to posts. 

Before: 

After: 

 

  • TKB Documents: The last edited date has been added to TKB Documents to indicate the date on which a TKB was last updated in addition to it's creation date. This will make it easier for you to identify in the activity feeds if an article has been updated since it was first published. 

Before: 

After:  

 

  • New Progression Badges for Discussion: We launched another badge progression set, which is designed specifically to recognize members who start discussions. You will be rewarded with the first badge for starting your first discussion, the second for three discussions, the third for ten, and the fourth for twenty. The biggest milestone is the fifth badge, awarded for starting fifty discussions in the community. Caroleigh Deneen gave more details in her blog post here. 

 

  • Preserving the integrity of the community's content: It is highly recommended that if you need to use GenAI tools to draft, plan, and refine your content, the final text still reflects your personal expertise. Now the ‚ÄúGenAI Assisted Content‚Äù label can also be found and added. SAP¬¥s‚ÄØAnne Petteroe‚ÄØexplained all the details on‚ÄØher blog post here, and the examples of unacceptable usage. The complete‚ÄØgenerative AI guidelines for the SAP Community‚ÄØcan be found in our‚ÄØWelcome Corner‚ÄØgroup.‚ÄØ 

2025 Enhancements Recap!  

This year was full of new features and enhancements for the SAP Community. It is always good to look back and reflect on everything that was delivered at the end of the year. So, in case you missed any announcements or would like to know more about them, here is the complete list of everything that was delivered in 2025: 

January Enhancements - Read the full blog post here‚ÄØ  

  • "Creation Date" sort option added to viewing discussion threads within Groups 
  • ‚ÄúSubscribe‚Äù button to turn on all the notifications when comments and answers are posted to a blog post or a discussion. 
  • Time for Event Save the Date pages automatically adjusted accordingly to the user's browser time zone setting.

February Enhancements‚ÄØ- Read the full blog post here   

  • SAP Managed tag picker for search results sorted alphabetically‚ÄØand shows all results matching the search term 
  • Improvement to the SAP Managed tag page to show only the latest posts, side widgets removed, preview of the posts and Kudo counter was added  
  • Inclusion of BlueSky icon and link in notifications. Find our SAP Community profile at BlueSky here. 

March Enhancements - Read the full blog post here 

  • Update on the SAP Community Privacy Statement, with SAP Consulting Capability process description and addition of locations for the country and regional provision section 
  • Editor Bar fully expanded for better usage 
  • SAP Champions and Mentors identification by their logos 
  • Event reminders for 24h prior the event start 
  • Board selector list organized and sequenced inside ‚ÄúCreate a Post‚Äù 
  • Fixed Bugs 

We launched blog posts to the Community Corner group - Read the full blog post here   

  • For a better organization and optimize the accessibility for community content (that is not directly related to Technology or SAP products topics), a new blog post board has been created in the Community Corner group. This board is open to everyone for publishing a wide range of topics related to the SAP Community, including non-work-related content. On our side, we will use the new board to highlight active contributors, share updates about SAP Champions and Mentors, and post news related to SAP and community events. Existing Blog It Forward and Monthly Member Spotlight posts have already been moved there. The group is now also easily accessible via the main Groups navigation under Interest Groups. 

We launched the Community Feedback list - Read the full blog post here‚ÄØ  

  • Available inside the Community Corner‚ÄØgroup, the Feedback list is for the SAP Community team to provide continuous updates on submitted ideas, feedback, and bugs. Although it is not possible for members to publish their direct ideas, all the feedback that has been published in the discussions or sent via inbox will be added by the team. This is a common place to track the progress of enhancements, bugs, and errors. Users can also like and comment on the different items in the list, which helps understand what must be changed/prioritized.  

SAP Glow: New Design- Read the full blog post here  ‚ÄØ  

  • Launch of the new design platform from Project Glow. Elements of the redesign included the introduction of‚ÄØ72 font‚ÄØ(SAP‚Äôs typeface), new iconography (and removal of pictograms), and a lighter aesthetic and softer shape. 

Humanizing moderation- Read the full blog post here  

  • Introduction of a new process for identifying why the moderation alert has been raised. By differentiating non-DSA and DSA reports, we took a step to make moderation friendlier, but we continue ensuring that SAP Community complies with DSA, protecting our site and our members from the illegal activities that the regulations cover. 

August Enhancements- Read the full blog post here   

  • Share buttons (Copy link, Bluesky and LinkedIn) available in blog posts, questions, discussions, events, and knowledge-based documents 
  • Fixed bugs in the notifications page 
  • Sort Options inside the knowledge base, allowing to sort documents by creation date, most recent, most viewed, most commented, and most liked. 

New Q&A badges- Read the full blog post here  ‚ÄØ  

  • Badges for answering questions that were accepted as a solution. Is it possible to earn up to five badges, depending on the number of solutions you provided in Q&A. 

Dark Mode and new Events calendar- Read the full blog post here   

  • Expansion of the Events page with filtering options for countries and a filter for SAP Managed Tags that allows you to get specific when searching for events that match your interests. 
  • Dark-mode options started to be available on the platform, but it is still in a beta phase. 

Badges for kudos received- Read the full blog post here  ‚ÄØ  

  • To improve SAP Community gamification rewards, we launched the progression set of badges for Kudos received, starting from 1 up to 500 Kudos. 

Badges for kudos given - Read the full blog post here ‚ÄØ  

  • Considering the progression set for Kudos received, we also recognized the members given support by launching the badges for Kudos given as well.  

New intelligent search - Read the full blog post here  

  • Beta Search introduced several new filtering options, including the ability to filter by SAP Managed Tag and by question status such as unanswered questions. 

Blog posts published badges - Read the full blog post here   

  • Brand new progression set exclusively for bloggers, rewarding members that have been published from 1 blog post to 30 publications.  

New developer forums - Read the full blog post here   

  • ‚ÄØNew home‚ÄØfor our developers and technical audience in the SAP Community with the following topics:‚ÄØABAP, Artificial Intelligence, SAP CAP, Data and Analytics, Frontend / UI5 / SAP Fiori, Integration and Tooling, including SAP Build. 

September Enhancements- Read the full blog post here  ‚ÄØ  

  • New Standards for Tags and Labels that Enables only 10 SAP Managed Tags, user tags and ten labels per piece of content.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 
  • <code> tag -‚ÄØAbility to inline <code> HTML element in the body of a post, which will be displayed its contents styled in a colored monospaced font.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 
  • Table of Contents (TOC) -‚ÄØFunctionality that allows you to add the Table of Contents for blog posts and documents (Knowledge Base articles).‚ÄØ This button will open a ‚ÄúManaged Table of Contents‚Äù to give you a preview and options overview.‚ÄØ 
  • Dismissible Global Banner -‚ÄØThe team heard our members request and now it is possible to find the button ‚ÄúX‚Äù in the banner, which will be removed until a new banner is added.  
  • Glow/Dark were fixed and now the Label widget has been hidden in some boards, the ‚ÄúBoard‚Äù word has also been removed from the top of the feed (allowing the content to be moved up) and ‚Äúspacing‚Äù around headers in post is fixed.‚ÄØ 
  • The Creation Date sorting option has been added to all feeds, making it easier to organize and view posts when they were created. 

Happy Holidays! 

With your support and constant engagement, we can continue spreading high-quality information about various SAP Topics and create a strong community worldwide. It is great to count on your collaboration and feedback to keep our platform moving. We wish you an incredibly happy end of the year and that you have a wonderful time enjoying the holidays! See you next year!
